comment.author: 51035743246@N01
comment._content: It seems surprising to me that suffragettes would resort to arson. I wondered if the fire was really caused by reactionaries trying to make them look bad but apparently not. Were suffragettes more militant than I realized or were they more militant in Great Britain than the US? Here are a couple short articles in the New York Times dated March 11, 1913 which mention the fire. [1],[2] The date on this photo is currently set to 'some time in 1910. It should probably be set to March 11, 1913, or at least 'some time in 1913'.

comment.author: 27073477@N00
comment._content: Let’s hear it for Mrs. Pankhurst! SUFFRAGETTES TRY TO REACH THE KING 3/10/1910 New York Times … "Mrs. Pankhurst read the petition which it had been desired to present to the King. It declared that the militant movement for votes for women was endangering all forms of public and private property and had brought the administration and the law in to contempt." “All thinking persons”, it went on, “were eagerly and impatiently waiting to see whether the speech from the throne would contain a promise of legislation by which the suffragists’ violence and its consequences could be brought to append. “Votes for women” it continued, “Is the only cure for militancy. The revolting and futile policy of releasing hunger-strikers and re-arresting them, and again releasing them and re-arresting them, would simply bring discredit upon the Ministers responsible for it. Such treatment will never break the spirit of the women, though it will very likely bring about a tragedy, for although the women cannot be defeated they can be killed by persecution. If law and order are to be re-established in this realm, women must have votes.”

comment.author: 34441597@N00
comment._content: Good For Mrs Pankhurst! And, just in case someone is interested, the firm Suttons Seeds is still alive and well. Here is their history on their website www.suttons.co.uk/History.htm -- Seen on your photo stream. (?)

comment.author: 97317828@N00
comment._content: The railway station has its own Wikipedia entry which mentions this incident: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saunderton_railway_station

comment.author: 14936048@N07
comment._content: I never knew that suffragists resorted to terrorism.  That's something the history books omit.

comment.author: 61849735@N00
comment._content: There was a Masterpiece Theatre drama about the movement.  I think the title was The Pankhursts.  Not sure.   You can probably buy it on DVD from PBS.  The 2 things I remember most from it were they burning letters placed in mail receptacles.  And the force feedings when the women were in prison.  Some died from it.

comment.author: 11572312@N00
comment._content: @ Great Photo... (re terrorism and suffragettes) here is another photo from this same Library of Congress series of results of a large fire started by the suffragettes: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2765476716/

comment.author: 8368002@N03
comment._content: This is fascinating. Thanks to LOC for posting these photos, and to those who have more information.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
Thanks to all for the interesting discussion and the additional information.  

Dawn Endico: We’re still working on getting the dates to match! When we first uploaded the photos, we didn’t have 4-digit years in all our records, so we used an early default date for each set.

comment.author: 32139046@N07
comment._content: The station was burnt down by Agnes Olive Beamish (aka Phyllis Brady) and her fellow suffragette friend Elsie Duvall (aka Millicent Dean). Both spent many years in prison for other acts of arson, mainly for setting fire the a house belonging to Lady White. Elsie managed to avoid going to prison for this by fleeing to France. Olive (she preferred to be known by her middle name) was not so lucky. I knew Olive in her later years, and you would never have guessed her past life and experiences by looking at the old lady! She died in 1978. Elsie died in 1919.
